content:
y 23, 2015
												Dawn of War is one of the first "real" Warhammer 40k RTS games to ever hit PC´s.You get to follow Gabriel Angelos as he uncovers a major plot in the Tartarus campaign, this is the first game in a long series of Warhammer 40k games that was created by Relic while they where still owned by THQ, also the very first game where we got to see the Blood Ravens as they where created purely as a "PC Game" chapter.Story wise the game is as good as you can do with an RTS, you get a deep sense of where Gabriel Angelos comes from and what his goals are as you get deeper and deeper into the game the story changes and there are some major plot twists all the time. Graphic wise Dawn Of War is an old game and that is visible, however SEGA (now owners of Relic) keeps supporting the game and recently even released a patch to deal with some of the issues that had been around for awhile, this is despite the fact the game came out in 2004 which makes it over 10 years old now.Gameplay wise DoW is very straightforward, you build bases and kill stuff as any other RTS, however the way that Relic gave us the Warhammer universe with the Dawn of War series is amazing, you get a deep feeling for your chapter and your enemies, you get some great story and a great experience as you go through the missions one by one. Even now the multiplayer is very much alive and working very well, you get to pick between Space Marines, Orks, Elder or Chaos Space Marines which gives you a great chance for some epic battles, Relic even included the option to paint your own army and use it online. All in all a great game for old RTS fans and even more so if you are into the Warhammer 40.000 Universe.

content:
ry 23, 2014
This is a long review, so if you just want a summary of why I recommend Dawn of War Gold Edition then skip to the Results section and reading from there.Relic Entertainment works with Games Workshop to produce an epic real time strategy game that pushed the boundaries of the genre. Dawn of War offers economics, base building, military tactics, and unit management. Story:Dawn of War, the first installment on an incredible Warhammer 40,000 saga. The game is based on the planet Tarturus where Ork forces are out of control ravaging the planet and destroying Imperial Guard moral; but, how are they winning so easily? Of course the forces of Chaos are behind the whole war. Dawn of War is the story of Gabrial Angelos and Isador Akios and how they work together to figure out the whole reason behind the presence of Chaos on the imperial garrison at Tarturus. Campaign:The campaign offers an epic tale into the 40k lore with amazing twists and turns around every mission. Coupled with the amazing combat system, base management, and resource management this game really packs a punch. The campaign is divided into eleven missions which put you to the test fighting against the Orc Horde and the Chaos Might. As you progress through the campaign you work with the Eldar to defeat a common foe, but as the game dictates the Enemy of your Enemy is not always your friend. The game pits teams together, but at the same time continually draws them apart. Gameplay:This game was one of the first to successfully introduce rapid base expansion by requiring players to capture strategic points, which give the player a trickle of endless resources over time. The fast paced gameplay coupled with the macro and micro unit management really made this game a force to be reckoned with. Although the unit population seems rather low (20 personal – 10 vehicle) because the units are based in squads the real unit count is much higher. The battles seem more like full scale wars with you gripping to manage all your units at once. The best feature of this game (and all the Dawn of War games) is that each team is completely different. They have different units, different buildings, upgrades, tactics, resource types, hero units, and strategies. For example the Orc play completely different from the Eldar while both the Eldar and Orcs play completely different from the Space Marines and Chaos Marines. The only two similar teams are the Space Marines and Chaos marines which offer a good learners curve to Dawn of War by giving providing a basic approach to strategy: build barracks, build turrets for defense, use main base to upgrade to new “age” to receive better buildings, build power plants to get power, and upgrade units within armory, etc. Teams:There are four teams: Space Marines, Eldar, Orcs, and Chaos Marines. Each team poses different tactics/strategic elements which make you play them differently. The Orcs are based more around unit massing and rapid base expansion. While the Eldar are more about unit specialization and micro base management. The Space Marines and Chaos Marines are essentially the same team set, and fit between tactics of the Orcs and Eldar. Each of the teams units have upgradeable attributes which customize them for specific purposes: weapons, additional squad members, and squad leader units. Each team has special commander units which can be used as heroes buffing the team and supporting military units.Results:All and all Dawn of War is a must get game. If you can play older games without constantly yearning for the graphics of the modern day games then you’ll enjoy this game. The gameplay is not outdated, but rather refreshing. As it seems most strategy game developers have diverted from base building, resource management, and mass scale war to simple micromanagement tactic games. I loved this game and all the installments so much I repurchased them all on steam. Despite that I still have all the discs, in functional condition, right next to me. Pros:+Economic, Base building, and macro unit management+Fantastic story and campaign (which is very rare in a strategy game)+Amazing teams which each play completely differently.+Fast paced gameplay which requires expansion to acquire resource nodes (but those nodes do not run out like in most games)+Unit customization allows you to create squads for specific tasks+Fantastic computer AI that puts you to your witsCons:-Cannot play this game while having another monitor running (if you have two monitors the game will launch but every time you move the mouse to the edge of the screen where your monitor extends the mouse exits the game as if you are playing in Windowed mode).-Lots of unbalances (don’t worry they fix all of these in the later installments)

content:
r 6, 2015
												Dawn of War is a fantastic modern RTS that measures up very well against the greats in the genre like Starcraft and Age of Empires. It takes place in the Warhammer 40k universe but manages to appeal to players who aren't familiar with the tabletop or lore such as myself. Dawn of War unlike most "older" rts games isn't focused on building or resource gathering. You gain resources automatically through capturing "strategic points" around the map and stealing them from other players. This encourages exploring the map and assaulting other players very quickly early on. Building is also done very early on so the majority of what you spend your time on is creating units and attacking players.Combat in Dawn of War is done very well. Because there's very little micromanagement with resources and buildings you spend most of the game creating squads, upgrading those squads with different weapons and assaulting the enemy. Each of the 4 races are familiar but different enough so that you'll quickly pick out a favorite among them. Dawn of War's greatest asset is speed, games go by very quickly and you are always getting rewarded for the smallest of accomplishments like capturing strategic points. Which stack up greatly as the game goes on. There are also a lot of little details to the game like how Space Marine buildings are generated by being dropped from orbit. The real unfortunate aspect about this release (The original Game of the Year edition) is it's arguably the one I'd recommend the least. It only contains four of the core races (Space Marines, Eldar, Chaos Space Marines and Orks) along with a fairly lackluster Blood Ravens campaign. I still do recommend getting it since it does introduce you to the mechanics of the game very well, and those races do port over to the multiplayer of the subsequent expansions. But by itself the Game of the Year edition isn't as impressive as Winter Assault or Dark Crusade.

content:
8, 2014
												10 Years Later, And It Keeps On Giving!Ive always been a massive fan of the Wh40K Universe, and my love for Games Workshop and all things related, started 10 years ago with this game! I remember my brother pre-ordering  it, and he introduced me into the Universe, and I spent many years watching him play DoW. A few years later, I managed to get my hands on the great title, having been handed down a little beast of a PC ( or had been at the time anyway), and it was my first chance to unleash the power of the Space Marines unto those nasty orks, and the heretic forces of chaos. It was a 3 disk installation, and about a 3 hour wait ; before the game was properly onto the PC. It was well worth it, and the expansions that came out along the years added to the mayhem, it was all part of the experience. I stopped playing DoW as I got rid of my computer, as it was well outdated, and then I suppose it got forgotten in time.Now back in present day, I became a part of the Steam community, and thought id dig around the room for some games I could add to steam. I found this little gem on my top shelf, so I thought I would give it a go and enter the cd key into steam, I was awfully excited! Put it onto my little laptop, 30 minute installation and I was away, ( so much for those 3 hours installs eh). It all came back to me when I started playing it once again, the music, the classic call of the space marines charging into battle. Me chanting “Burn The Heretic!”, while my Space Marines shoot the hell out of a squad of Chaos marines. Yes, all those requirements of a great RTS game, with hours and hours of enjoyment. You cannot go wrong with good old Dawn Of War, or rather i cannot anyway. The graphics may be quite outdated, and the multiplayer doesn’t hold much of a feature in the game nowadays,  however that certainly does not hinder any enjoyment at all.  Fan of the Wh40k Universe? Used to own the game, but not sure whether to return to serve the emperor? I recommend purchasing this game, and having a whole lot of fun playing it! I personally have a great deal of more of hours to enjoy on this game, reliving the moments of destruction and chaos. In terms of gameplay elements, Dawn Of War still does not fail to be a very fun, and a practically great game. 10 Years Later And It Sure As Hell Keeps On Giving!Overall:+ Everything a classic RTS needs+ Clever resource system+ Immersive campaign to sink many hours into+ Must buy for Warhammer 40k fans+ Still great at 10 years of age- Multiplayer servers not great- Outdated Graphics- Minor bugsSolid 9/10That goes it for my short Dawn of War Steam Review.Thanks,The-Sentinel-Gamer

2016
Basic InformationTitle:  Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War - Game of the Year EditionDeveloper:  Relic EntertainmentPublisher:  SEGAGenre:  Real Time StrategyGeneral ImpressionOne of the best Sci-Fi 3D RTS to date and the classic of an established franchise which sparked a Dawn of War trilogy as of 2016. With just the right amount of base management and plenty of brutal combat, it is far better than many similar RTS games. I remember the first time playing it, more than a decade ago and I was amazed by the fact that you can have hundreds of fallen units on the battlefield and they wouldn't vanish within seconds, like they do in almost all the other real-time strategies. The graphical details have aged well and they can be enjoyed even without texture mods. If you would consider skipping this title and going directly for Dawn of War II or play the upcoming III, think again. DoW I is still a worthy RTS experience and always will be.Strong Points+ Beautiful graphics and sounds.+ Excelent setting and storyline.+ Steam Trading Cards.Weak Points- No Achievements.Rating 10/10 This review was submitted for Imperial Reviews and Cubbes.

content:
ry 3, 2016
												Watching a beloved franchise move between mediums is always difficult. Sometimes it is the awkward transition from movie to videogame. Other times it is the even more awkward transition from videogame to movie. However, every once in a while a franchise weathers the change well, some might argue better off because of the move. The Warhammer 40,000 universe, deftly crafted by the folks at Games Workshop, has attempted the move to videogames before, meeting with varying levels of success. However, it is truly Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War that has made video game players aware of the tabletop brand. Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War is a real-time-strategy title that recreates the epic tabletop battles of the Warhammer 40k universe, almost perfectly, on your PC. Epic is truly the best word to describe some of these battles as Space Marines and Imperial Guard do their best to hold off the war hungry Orks, the mysterious Eldar, and destroy the twisted forces of Chaos. Dawn of War does an excellent job of staying true to the source material, both in story and gameplay. Specifically, the gameplay for DoW has shifted the focus from individual troops to squads of soldiers. Morale of these squads also plays a role in how combat plays out with "broken" squads becoming significantly less effective until they can regroup. Just as special characters also play a large role in the tabletop game, they make a significant impact on your Dawn of War army. Force Commanders, Librarians, Sergeants, and Apothecaries can all be attached to your Space Marine squads to imbue them with additional powers and improved combat skills. Access to these characters, as well as certain types of buildings, research topics, and vehicles is granted through a construction tree that will be instantly recognizable to anyone that has ever played a RTS game. That is one of the great things about Dawn of War, it is, at once, both familiar and new. As the heir apparent to the StarCraft legacy, Dawn of War had some large shoes to fill. Fortunately, it didn't try to replicate the StarCraft experience step for step. The shift to squad-based combat and completely redesigned resource management system have taught us all that there is no room in this world for a lone soldier or gathering crystals, gas, and trees on the battlefield. These adjustments fit the Warhammer 40k game model extremely well and keep the focus on the action, where it belongs. The 3D graphics engine behind Dawn of War's action does a great job of making the epic combat of the 40k universe a personal affair while maintaining the global view that you need to keep track of your forces. Zooming your camera all of the way into the action allows you to see every detail of what is going on in the middle of combat. The animations are tailored fabulously to the characters at hand and are extremely satisfying for those of us that have spent countless hours playing the tabletop game. There is nothing quite as satisfying as watching your Dreadnought grab an Eldar soldier, lift him into the air, and rend his body into a bloody pulp. Okay, maybe watching your Whirlwind's missile battery send Orks flying across the battlefield can match it. Whatever your preference, the combat is visceral when you get up close and personal. It is just a shame that the camera can't back out just a little bit farther as the somewhat limited field of view makes it a little bit tricky to keep an eye on a large force. Because of this, using rally points and the quick assignment keys become mandatory in managing your troops. Multiplayer is standard fare in real-time-strategy games and Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War dishes up a pretty satisfying variety of maps and races with which you can wage war. Each of the game's four main races, Space Marine, Ork, Eldar, and Chaos are playable in multiplayer and while the matches can degrade to a battle of numbers, the inclusion of strategic points definitely mixes things up a bit. How does Dawn of War stack up to the original tabletop game? Some of the Warhammer 40k nuts out there might disagree with the RTS adaptation of the turn based game. They also might complain that not every vehicle or troop made the jump to the PC. These kind of objections to DoW are nitpicky and don't take into account that this is truly a great real-time-strategy game.There is no question why so many gaming enthusiasts voted Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War the top real-time-strategy game when it came out and the game is still one of the best RTS titles in existence. A few minor camera flaws are easily overshadowed by the visceral combat experience that Dawn of War offers.

content:
y 13, 2015
												I'm a huge RTS fan, but for whatever reason, I never picked this up until recently. I was introduced to the Warhammer 40,000 universe by way of the Warhammer 40,000: Space Marine third person shooter, which I greatly enjoyed. This universe has intrigued me since then, and I have tried to catch up with the more long-term fans of the franchise by reading up on the lore and such online. It's quite different from most fantasy; where magic and medieval type weaponry is common in fantasy, Warhammer has a refreshing spin on things, relying more on machinery and gunplay while keeping the magic and awe the fantasy genre offers to players. It also falls in the area of dystopian, which is by far my favorite genre of any entertainment, and it is interesting to have a protagonist in this game whose ideals and beliefs could be viewed as fanatical by our standards, but would be understandable in such a future where he serves beneath a totalitarian empire.Moving on from the universe to the gameplay, Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War is an RTS that is unique in its approach to a genre that is tried and true. Whereas many RTS games focus on base building and annihilation, this game simplifies the base building and relies more on strategical points that you must capture for resource generation throughout the map. Each campaign or skirmish mission "gets going", so-to-speak, much more quickly than other RTS games. You spend less time buiding and more time moving your armies along the map. For those that find some in the genre to be slow moving in the beginning, Dawn of War brings a welcome change. Something else that Dawn of War does well that not enough RTS games do (sometimes at all) is reinforcements and upgrades. Where some games have you upgrade units from their respective recruitment centers and it encompasses all units of the same type, Dawn of War gives you more choice in how you want them upgraded. You can build a group of Space Marines, add reinforcements (making an initial group of four into up to eight), add sergeants later on, commanders, etc. In addition, with upgrades you can have a few men within the group upgrade their weapons, and the selection of weapons is up to you. You can have four rocket launchers, two rocket launchers, one flamethrower, and a laser pistol, or any combination between. This gives the player an ability to build up a small army for one intention (rocket launchers are great at taking out vehicles and buildings, for example), while creating another for a different intention (sending a differently equipped army to fight infantry). Even within firefights, you can reinforce your army if you possess the resources, giving the player a second chance in battle when most RTS games give none.Lastly, it should be noted that I am a single player only strategy player, so I buy games like this for the campaign and skirmishes. In saying that, this game's campaign is fantastic. While somewhat short (eleven missions and about 15 hours of gameplay; note that Steam did not track all of my game time), the story is quite good and involving, taking you across many different types of landscapes and introducing you to different races to fight against. The cutscenes are a bit stilted due to the game's age, and the voice acting (while over-dramatic at times) is fantastic. The missions are vast and varied, and the game never gets in the habit of annoying you with time limits (I hate timed missions in any game, personally). The missions were challenging without being impossible, and they were friendly to both players who like to rush and complete the missions, and players like me, who like to leisurely explore the whole map and take over all positions before deciding to fully vanquish my enemy. Skirmishes are available, offering a few dozen maps that you can choose to play on, giving you choices as to what colors your army wears to which races you fight against, along with a whole myriad of other choices to make to tweak your gameplay if you so choose. In summary, Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War is a fantastic RTS title that makes me very happy I purchased the Master Collection of games, because I am looking forward to experiencing more of this interesting universe. I would recommend it to any fans of RTS, as well as those looking to get into the genre, as this game is extraordinarily user friendly and has a fantastic tutorial. If you are unsure, I urge you to try the demo. I played the demo some time before buying the game and loved what it offered, so it is a fair representation of the game. I can see myself adding this to a list of games I come back to every now and then, because it offers a truly unique strategy experience that stands apart from others. I went into this game with no expectations other than what I'd read through some of the reviews, and after beating it, I consider myself a fan.

content:
22, 2014
												"Beware the Alien, the Mutant, the Heretic"'Warhammer 40K: Dawn of War' is, simply put, one of the best Real-Time Strategy games on the market - A blood-soaked odyssey through the Warhammer 40k Universe - filled with Imperial Space Marines, Ork Hordes, Eldar and The Forces of Chaos. Campaign: Released in 2004 by Relic Entertainment, 'Dawn of War's' brutal opening cinematic sets the stage for what awaits within - a savage battlefield across the Imperial Planet of Tartarus where the local population have been suddenly beset by Ork Hordes. As Commander of the Space Marines (The Emperor's Personal Guard), you begin a quest to push back the Orks and determine why they are on the planet. A deep and engaging story-fueled campaign takes you from cities to lost ruins, from mountains lairs to the planets icy tundras, leading a tech heavy force of Space Marines, Mech Walkers, Artillery Tanks, Predator Tanks and Terminator Assault Squads, to unearth the cause of this strange heresy plaguing the planet. Gameplay | Graphics | Sound:  Gameplay is centered around a combination of basebuilding, resource management, unit management, and battlefield tactical combat. Unlike other RTS games however, you will not spend a lot of downtime collecting resources as the game is focused on capturing 'Strategic Points' on the battlefield which keep the onus always on the forward movement of your army. The action is always fast, frenetic and bloody, and always around the next bend in the road. For a game released in 2004, the graphics are a tad dated, but generally hold up extremely well during gameplay. Great sound quality, a phenomenal soundtrack and responsive M&K controls round out a well polished title.Overall, 'Dawn of War' is a title of legend - one of the finest RTS games of its generation and a must-have for any Strategy gamer. The campaign is deeply satisfying, gameplay is polished, the battles are bloody and unapologetically violent, and somehow you cannot help but be drawn into the Warhammer universe of Orks and Mutants, Heretics and Socerers, Daemons and Blood Gods. "Forward, ..For the Emperor!" - (Rated 9.5 /10)

content:

												I remember walking through the store and finding some milk. I held it up and looked at the price tag. I remembered that I already had two cartons of milk at home, and I though to myself "What am I buying this for?" Then suddenly, as if possesed by a ghost, I screamed aloud "FOR THE EMPEROR!" That was the moment of my enlightenment. I had discovered my puropse in life. Whenever I see someoe backing into a parking space I roll down my windows and yell "Claim it in the name of the emperor!" I find myself painting blood ravens on yield signs and kneeling down in front of them. When a freind asked me if I wanted to go see Captain America I responded "Faith is my shield" My doctor said that I have a benign tumor in my brain. I slaughtered the heretic, the mutant, the alien. FOR THE GLORY OF THE IMPERIUM!

Heck, grab the entire collection when it goes on a sale. Every single game has its own value and they're worth every dollar.

												An absolutely brilliant adaption of the Warhammer 40,000 tabletop game to real-time strategy.  Relic hits it out of the park in nailing the look and feel of Warhammer 40K, while providing for fluid real-time gameplay - including base building. content:
er 9, 2016
Product received for free
												I have to admit, this game really surprised me. Not only is it a solid strategy game in its own right, but it's a fantastic gateway into a universe that's simulateniously a grim, miserable world of a humanity in constant fanatical fear of treachery and kind of an insane goofy sci-fi version of "Orcs vs. Humans" with guns and a unapologetic disregard for life. I find it kind of funny that the unit designs are what I expect the minitures to look like. Mechanically, it runs like a mutation of all the other strategy games I've played, such as StarCraft, Star Wars: Empire at War, and even Army Man RTS.Most of my problems with the game are largely technical, such as I think the camera is a little small. I only learned units could be added into your group with a Crtl-click 10 hours in. I do like that units can be part of more than one group, that's proven helpful. The only problem is that when I try to move my epic Space Marine army en masse, they can easily get in their own damn way through what I can only assume is a combination of troublesome collision programming and pathfinding AI. I don't know if this is Relic's way of encouraging me to split my forces, but that seems more like something you would do after hours of experience and not right off the bat so it just felt frustrating.While these problems are note-worthy, they do not detract from the experience in any meaningful way. I have no idea what the expansions and sequels are like, but I'm definitely interested in buying them.9/10

number of helpful: 14 of 15 people (93%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
y 10
												Dawn of War, if I was held at gunpoint and had to choose one RTS out of all of them, it would be this. I love Warhammer 40,000 with a passion  and I love RTS games. With that simple mixture it has easily won my heart over. However with the up and coming Dawn of War III is Dawn of War still relevant after all these years? It's been over a decade now and many people have mixed opinions on that subject. My objective with this review is to inform consumers whether or not they are making a good purchase as well as share my own view if the game is still worth getting even after Dawn of War III's release. The Plot In the grim dark universe of 40k we start the story like any other in the Warhammer universe, massive invasion of Orks attacking an Imperial controlled world blowing stuff up and slaughtering thousands of innocents for ♥♥♥♥♥'n'giggles. Our hero and Force Commander is Gaberial Angelos, captain of the Blood Ravens. He has been sent to Tartarus to counter attack the greenskin scum and look bad ♥♥♥ while doing it. While on the planet Angelos, and Isador Akios (a Psyker) discover that Orks are not the only thing on Tartarus. The Eldar have set up a beach head and are trying to protect an ancient relic from being discovered by the evil forces of Chaos.And that's basically the story without spoilers. I think it is to be expected out of RTS games that the developer's attention is more on the mutliplayer than the campaign. So expecting a space opera of some sort in an RTS is the first step on the road to disappointment. But at least it gets the job done and it introduces the player to the mechanics of the game through a narative. The Multiplayer Since I am assuming you are either buying this game for the base factions, or you are getting into Warhammer 40k for the first time, I will dig into the real gutts of this game. The mutliplayer.Let's start off with the factions: Space Marines Space Marines are genetically and cybernetically enhanced super humans that were created by the holy Emperor to conquer the galaxy and maintain order when that objective was completed. This faction is highly recommended for new players simply for how durable, defensive, and fairly adaptable they are. They start out with simple bolt guns and bolt pistols but you can customize some squad's loadouts on the fly like for example; Tactical Marines with the following: Flamers, Heavy Bolters, Plasma Guns, and Rocket Launchers. Each of these serve a purpose for different enemies you may encounter on the battlefield. They also have melee units such as Assault Marines that can jump in and out of combat. Making them great for breaking enemy morale and breaking ranged unit lines. Space Marines also possess a wide range of vehicles to crush their enemies with holy fury. Overall the Space Marines are just a great faction. They look cool, they function properly, but they aren't overly powerful. The Orks Orks are chaotic, dangerous, silly, and insane all at the same time. They eat they sing they laugh and they slaughter and that's pretty much all Orks do. Make the tribe bigger and rush the enemy with a lot of numbers. Of course for balancing reasons you can't just trample the guy/gal you're fighting 2 minutes into the game. You have to build what is called "WAAAAAAGH! banners" let's just call them WB's for short. You have to build WB's in order to gain the WAAAAAGH! resource as well as increase the population cap. This can take a while for an inexperienced player so I recommend reading guides. I've played for hundreds of hours and even I have trouble keeping up with their tiers.But when you do get a ahead? Orks are a tough bunch and will not go down easily. Their advanced units are also pretty brutal to anything they come into contact with. Thus it is important to stay ahead of Orks as best you can or else it is game over. Now I can see people saying they are OP because of this, but their basic units can die pretty easily. They may have some decent super units, but they still need the numbers and resources to maintain themselves. The Eldar The Eldar are a dying race of (basically) space elves. They have increadibly advanced technology as well as a vast wealth of knowledge of the webway. It is because of their webway mechanic they are considered OP. They can go almost anywhere on the entire map with their webway gates as well as support themselves with their stealth and healing auras. If you are ever fighting an Eldar player or A.I opponent, expect to be going on an hour long goose chase to find where their real base is. Generally people just give up and rage quit leaving the Eldar player victorious for doing absolutely nothing but move to a new hiding spot every time the transport cooldown is over. So it basically rewards players that didn't try to preserve their army and are more than willing to hide their base rather than play the game. The only real drawback to this is that Eldar as a whole require a lot of RTS experience and mirco in order to play properly. Chaos Space Marines Chaos Space Marines or CSM for short are a horny asset flip of the Space Marines....Alright alright I'll go into more detail. CSM were loyal Space Marines that turned to Chaos during the Horus Heresy. An event that caused a civil war between Space Marines, the Emperor, and his own children. CSM are not necessarily as durable or adaptable as their loud and proud brothers. But make up for this with raw DPS, devastating armored vehicles, and teleporting Daemons they can drop in to cause more havoc. There are only two problems with the Chaos faction as a whole, one: Chaos Heretics have one of the most annoying voices I have ever heard in a videogame. And two: Other than Daemons, they don't have much that makes them stand out or make them act differently from the Space Marines. Same models (but with horns) same, animations, and half of the same weapons. I personally think Dawn of War 2 did a much better job at depicting CSM and making them stand out....Well there was this one time Alpha Legion broke the lore by summoning a Daemon of Nurlge but that's a story for another time. The Final Verdict For a 40k game, 4/5. For an RTS game? I would say 8/10 is pretty fair. It has stood the test of time proudly, and while it's game balance is questionable Dawn of War has provided something very few 40k games have managed to capture. And that is the vast combat of the universe and setting it is in. 40k games these days have either had potential but squandered it, or the developers have no idea what they are doing with an IP they barely understand. By all means leave your opinions down in the comments and if you have something to point out in the review I would be happy to hear it!

content:
er 16, 2014
												Solid start to the franchise however it has a few technical issues initially (lack of widescreen support, sluggish mouse/camera controls compared to its expansions and sequels).The story is regular grimdark stuff you'd expect from Warhammer 40K. It primarily focuses on the Blood Ravens chapter of the Space Marines so if you want a campaign which allows you to play other factions, then getting Dark Crusade would be a good idea as well (Soulstorm too, though that game also has its issues).Gameplay-wise this is the solid RTS we've come to know and love over the years. You control squads rather than individual units, some squads are customizable in terms of weapons such as Tactical marines to fit the current situation or need. If you really want to test yourself, play against the insane AI on quick start either by yourself or with friends, you will experience some of the most frantic and gloriously messy RTS battles of its time.All in all this edition of the original game is solid, though Dark Crusade would be an easier recommendation for those who do not want to deal with some of these technical issues.

												The crimson armoured figure strode across rubble, burning vehicles, and corpses alike. Blood caked it's armor, wide sploches of darkened ruby which were spread all over it's once majestic- yet still formidable -armor, and made it even more terrifying in the shining light of dawn. It stood at nearly 9 feet tall, fully armored, twin massive shoulder plates on each side of it, and a helmet of grinning death, piercingly green optics burning through the haze of weapons discharge and smoke alike. it raised it's massive blocky bolter rifle with exaggerated movements belying the immense strength behind it's arms, as it slowly aims it at me. It would be the last sight I would see, as drop pods streamed from the heavens behind the giant.This was the day the Ork Tyrant of Galgaris fell, alongside the rest of his Ork WAAAGH.This was also the day I shoved my power armored boot (and PC) up said WAAAGH's collective @$$ and joined the Space Marines. 40,000/10, would run over Ork encampments in a Land Raider, screaming "FOR THE EMPRAHHHHHH" as loud as the vox-systems in the cabin would allow me again with the rest of my squad watching on.

content:
er 26, 2015
												A classic real-time strategy game with excellent balance and an interesting campaign story.  Though the graphics may be well past their prime the mechanics of the game are still fun to this day.  I assume Dawn of War was truly a trendsetter in its time though this review in particular is being typed up by someone who first laid their hands on it in 2015.There are several aspects of this game that really hooked me in.  The fact that your units are -actually- units (small bands of soldiers) was a pleasant surprise.  Each unit can be reinforced, given time and requisition (currency), so it will continue to be an active part of your army as long as you replace your losses.  This prevents replacements from clogging up your new unit construction at your base and allows you to keep pressing your advantage without worrying about logistics as soldiers arrive on your frontlines instead of far behind them.  Additionally, I enjoyed being able to personally customize my own units.  If I wanted one unit of Space Marines to excel at eliminating other heavy infantry I could deck them out with a few plasma rifles while if I was going for more an anti-vehicle/building approach with that unit I could supply them with rocket launchers instead.Though I personally can't think of any complaints on the game as a whole other than stretching and pointing at the outdated graphics, I can say that I enjoyed the campaign far more than I did the random scenarios or multiplayer.  I found that I had a blast playing the game with objectives and a story but the Starcraft model of 'create a horde as fast as possbile and zerg the other base' got old quickly.  However, I am aware that there are -plenty- of players out there who would find that a great addition to the level of fun that they experience, not a detriment.I recommend this game to all RTS fans especially those who enjoy the more old-school variants.  I picked it up in a sale and got almost fifteen hours out of the Game of the Year version by itself; fifteen hours that I still believe were very well spent.

content:
5, 2014
												Dawn of War is an RTS set in the 40k universeStory:The game starts with a company of blood ravens being sent to the planet Tartarus to help the Imperial Guard with an Ork invasion, but shortly after they arrive they find evidence that the Orks aren't the only threat to the planet, with twists around every corner that ramp up the stakes.Gameplay:When it comes to macro, the only thing that I found to be different is that you get one of your resources by capturing points, other than that, micro isn't that special. Micro on the other hand, is made unique thanks to the squad system(there may be a game that has done this before but as of this review I don't know of an game before this that did the squad system) basically when you make a unit you don't get just the one unit, you get a squad of 4(initial units in each squad does vary for each race/unit type) and can then add more to the squad, and give them special weapons. This is nice mainly because it does mean that attacks where barely anyone survives won't be as devestating since you won't have to make a new batch of units and send them accros the map, as you can just reinforce squads, also it makes selecting a large group of units easier. And the fact that you can give your squads weapons means that you can make each squad have multiple purposes. Still if you've played an RTS before then this will feel a bit familiar but the things that the game has that most rts games don't will make it seem new and not more of the same. Overall this is an amzing game that I would recommend to anyone who likes rts or Warhammer 40k(it actually made me really intrested in 40k I even got the Dark Vengeance set because of this game).Note: This is my first review that took me more than a minute to write, if there was something that I could've done better or if there's something I forget to mention feel free to let me know(I already know my intro is kinda lackluster).

												Brilliantly articulated models for a game of it's age and very customisable in colours with 8 presets for each of the four main races. The Orks have there main strategy, outgun and outman the opponent and then overpower them. The Eldar have there snipers and magical elements with warlocks and the seer council showing their spedialty being long range then slice n' dice. The Space Marines are the standard force but seemingly the only ones (apart from the Chaos Space Marines) who can give a good defensive against the Orks and when they band together, they destroy the Orks with ease. The Chaos Space Marines are as close as you can get to pure evil and very similar to the Space Marines and if you spawn next to them from the start, there is no escape. This game plays very well and I can't compare it much to the boardgame as I never played it but the story is pretty good, I have nothing to argue there. This plays more like an RTS rather than Dawn of War II which is a TC or Tactical Command but both are still amazing and giev good variety between games. I recommend this game to RTS fans and Warhammer fans alike.

content:
y 13, 2015
												Dawn of War is a timeless classic. I've played this game years ago but it seems it hasn't lost any of it's sweetness.Here are some things that make Dawn of War different:Gameplay:1. Resource management is basically reduced to territory control. The more strategic points you control and the better you fortify them, the more of the 'requisition' resource you get.Investing into strategic point fortification, makes them harder to capture and after simple upgrade, they can shoot at your enemies. So you're basically building sentry turrets that mine resources for you. 2. Squad reinforcment Most units operate as squads. You get a squad of 4 marines, and you can add to it (reinforce) untill you got 8 marines. With upgrades you can add a sergeant who has a skill to rally them and instantly restore Morale. If few of your marines die, you can just reinforce the squad, and they will appear at the squad position at the fraction of a cost of a new squad. This allows you to push forward after a battle with little delay without moving new forces from base to the frontlines. 3. Squad equipment You can equip your squads with weapons effective against certain types of units, you can mix them up in one squad, or just have a dedicated squad for every type. This provides interesting choices and allows for more variety in your tactics.4. Cover Having your units sit in a bomb crater, behind a wall or in the trees, makes them harder to hit and they also feel better (see Morale)5. Morale Certain situations make units lose their composure and lower their effectiveness. Especially when they fight outnumbered, or against intimidating opponents or weapons (flamethrowers, snipers).6. Space considerations with 'macro'You need to think about the space your forces are going to operate in. You wont fit 3 tanks and 4 squads of infantry into a narrow street, without totally compromising their ability to efficiently move and operate. They will get stuck, bump into each other and wont be able to all get to the front to shoot the enemy you encounter. Some people say it's a downside and speak about "bugged pathing". Pathing is ok, it's just that Space Marines have "Space" in there for a reason :>If you fail to chose the path wide enough for your forces to move through comfortably, you're going to have to accept the fact they take much longer to get into position, and if they get attacked while the squad is not in tight formation, some of them will be in range to the enemy while others might not be. Settting:It's Warhammer 40k. In the Dark Grim Future there is only War. Space Marines aka "Adeptus Astartes" operate in chapters similar to battle-orders of old and live to fulfill the will of the God Emperor. They routinely drop from orbit in droppods, aWhole WH40k universe is full of awesomeness and I guarantee you wont regret getting into it. High production value:Dawn of War has some of the best voice acting in videogaming of last decade. Most buildings you build are dropped by your battle barge Litany of Fury from high orbit with a very loud "thump" when they impact (it's hard to call it landing). Animations of a dreadnaught cherry picking an orc from enemy squad, breaking his back while setting him on fire and then tossing him in an arc over 2 tanks and a squad of infantry are priceless. Blood is everywhere and in general you can set perment scaring and bodies, so your progress through the map can be marked with bodies of your enemies. TL;DR:Dawn of War is a game like no other, except it's successors in the Dawn of War series: Winter Assault, Dark Crusade, SoulstormTotally recommend to any and all fans of RTS games and/or WH40k universe.If you think you could like this game, but would like something with a bit more replayability (Dawn of War only has Space Marine campaign and skirmish/multiplayer) take a look at Dark Crusade and Soulstorm, which are a source of endless entertainment with their conqeur-the-planet style of gameplay and 7 different races to choose from.  Also be advised, that it's an old game and it has problems with wide-screen resolutions which might or might not be fixed.Myself I just played it in a 1280x1024 window. The same problem exists in Winter Assault, but Dark Crusade and Soulstorms are ok with any resolution in fullscreen.

er 1, 2013
												"In the grim darkness of the 41st millennium, there is only War" And thus was born, the most brutal tabletop game ever created. Loved by Painters, and board game addicts alike, the game finally jumped the boarder from tabletop to strategy game in 2004. Amoungst the StarCraft's of the industry, where E-sports are the primary focus sits this game. Absolutely terrific, fast paced, strategic force deployment where you're bound to see a 'Bloodthirster' tear of the head of the nearest spacemarine given the chance  This still remains my favourite RTS game all of time. Not to mention the terrific story which inspired multiple books and plot strings which carried over into it's latest sequel 'Dawn Of War II. If you any kind of fan of strategy games, you will no doubt, love this. A true gem in a sea of mediocre Warhammer games. (Firewarrior any?) If you can find this on sale, dont hesitate to snap this up. And as the Orks would say; "WAAAAAAAAAAAAAAHHHHHH!!!!"**************************************************************I would like to note that I've played this for years, just not on the steam version.

content:
y 19, 2016
												One of my favourite strategy games, and I am not a big strategy player at all. This game was the dawn of the Dawn of War series, and an outstanding game in its own right.In the single player campaign, you play as the Space Marines. Through various maps and settings, the story builds towards a handful of epic confrontations, and the difficulty progresses in like manner. Playing on normal is a little too easy, but push the difficulty up and you will find yourself challenged (disclaimer: I'm not very good at RTS games).Venture into multiplayer, and you will have four races at your disposal, each with their pros and cons: Chaos Marines, Elder, Orks and Space Marines. I found the multiplayer portion of the game to be well-balanced, with end game units strong but not so readily accessible to make one race overpowered.Lastly, if you're playing on any system built in the last seven-eight years, I HIGHLY recommend following the below guide to get widescreen resolutions working (all credit goes to OP):


Dawn of War Widescreen Fix 
A Guide for Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War - Game of the Year Edition
By: Ricyn

			  Warning only use this Method for Singleplayer and not for Multiplayer !   I couldn't get a answer if this is allowed since it is more than just .ini changes and they have new servers with protection after the...		


I used the modified files provided and they worked perfectly for me. Please read the first portion of the guide though: do not use these if you venture into the multiplayer!Overall, brilliant game. Any fan of Warhammer 40k or strategy in general needs to try this gem. Highly recommendedPlayed on Windows 10 Pro x64 without any problems.

content:
24, 2014
												There are two ways in which a real time strategy game can easily screw up.The first is to have far too much micro-management.The second is to feel limited in scale, ability or grandure.Warhammer 40k: Dawn of War expertly sidesteps both issues and delivers a fun, engaging campaign to save a planet from Ork invasion.Of course more is going on, and you will soon meet all of the other factions as well.What works so well in this game compared to most other strategy games is the fact that infantry units are comprised of squads of up to 10 individual soldiers. These can be tuned with new gear and restocked when they fall.It allows for an easy way to still have an impressive army steam-roll an enemy encampment without having to micro-manage everything.I had fun, and will definitely pick up the sequel (EDIT: Then I did, it's great too. Review here)Avoid this game if you can't stomach the dead-pan Space Marine seriousness though, it can get a bit much (and it's the only faction that has a campaign).

content:
ry 3, 2013
												DOW is an RTS with a bit of a deviation from the standard resource/base model seen in the likes of Starcraft or C&C. Instead, you obtain resources based on captured points and relics found around the map. Doing so prevents the "turtle in/mass army" tactic, as you are forced to expand outwards in order to gather. Gameplay wise, the game is very clearly a Relic game; and anyone who has played Company of Heroes will pick it up right away. Rather than build one unit at a time, you build squads of units. These squads can be upgraded with special weapons, or even link up with hero type units to greatly boost their ability. While members of the squad can die, you can reenforce them on the fly, making a squad feel more valuable than the sum of it's parts. Give it a try!

content:
, 2016
												This game is one of the finest RTS games ever to grace the genre. The game truly holds well even to this day, well over a decade afters its initial release. The game offers an interested and very fun singleplayer campaign where you play as the  Blood Ravens Space Marine chapter as they fight against a massive Ork force on an imperial planet. It's up to you to use your brain and tactical sense to destroy the Ork menace. But as time goes on the forces of Chaos arrive as well as the elusive Eldar and the stakes only begin to rise. The gameplay is solid. From the army commands as well as base building and management. Unlike other, older, RTS games the way you gain recources is by capturing and holding points that are around the battlemap making those areas complete hotspots for some epic large battles. You get to command large armies and pit them against other large armies, unique units and buildings per factions (four factions are available in the game), an army painter (very basic, but still fun to use custom armies in skirmish), and overall the game has a lot to offer. There are some downsides sadly, but these are more in the technical side rather than the game itself, the game does not support 16:9 resolutions, but with some mods you are able to force a 16:9 resolution in the game, but the mini map tends to bug out. The unit path finding can be a bit wonky at times as well and artillery units can be a real pain if you don't know how to properly use them, but overall nothing too serious, just minor inconveniences. This is a great game for both RTS fans and Warhammer 40k fans or if you're a fan of both, you're doing yourself an unjustice by not owning and playing this great game.

content:
er 11, 2012
												Dawn of War is one of the greatest single-player RPG's I have ever played. The WH40K franchise stories might sound incredibly cheesy on paper but you get control of your own company of Space Marines it just comes to life in a way few other franchises does. It makes you care about winning, it makes you care about the Empire.The gameplay is solid but nothing impressive. It maintains the standard resource based RTS gameplay but just replaces gold mines with strategic points. The units work great though, the sounds and looks of Space Marines and Ork's alike make them come alive and brings a great level of immersion.What takes Dawn of War from being just another solid RTS game to being a great RTS is not something that can be easily explained.It is the satisfaction you get from hearing the thump of a Thunderhammer impacting an Ork's skull. It is the sound of a heavy bolter opening fire from concealment. It is the Space Marine captain screaming "CHARGE" and rushing into certain death...

content:
, 2016
												In short, WH40K DOW is a good, slightly simplified RTS, with very few issues.The good:-This RTS is more focused on the fighting than the base building and defense. -The pacing is great and let's you go about the game at your own speed.-With on-the-spot reinforcements, retreating to defensive points to replenish your forces, helps get you back into the fight faster.-Great unit variety.-The game doesn't appear to cheat.-the maps have great strategic elements to them if you care to use them.The bad:-Awful unit pathfinding and targeting. Sometimes units just stand around not following orders.-Dated graphical elements that break or don't work at higher resolutions, such as an invisible mouse or out of frame minimap.-Doesn't support modern resolutions.-Game apparently doesn't work on Windows 10.

content:
r 8, 2016
												First of all, I'd recommend the Master Collection as a whole. The games are all worth playing through, and you have to own them all to use every race for online multiplayer in Dark Crusade/Soulstorm, if that matters to you.But let's say you're hesitant and want to buy them one at a time. That's cool too, and I'd certainly recommend starting here even if you buy the Master Collection. The Space Marine campaign this game offers is a great introduction to the series, and will serve you much better than throwing yourself into one of the more organic campaigns of Dark Crusade or Soulstorm.The gameplay is rather hard to describe, but the essential is that you build up your base, proceeding through tech-levels to unlock/produce more powerful units/vehicles, all while fighting for control of the resource points (the resources are needed for units/vehicles/buildings/upgrades) on the map and trying to destroy the enemy's base/not get yours destroyed. The victory conditions can vary, from destroying the enemy's headquarters, needing to eradicate them completely, or fighting for control of the difficult to defend "Critical locations" and holding a majority for a set amount of time (or completely eradication the enemy to end it faster).The base Dawn of War offers four races to skirmish with. The Space Marines, who are the only playable faction in the campaign, the Eldar, the Orks, and Chaos. One of the images in the slideshow shows the Sisters of Battle assaulting a Dark Eldar base, but that's from Soulstorm and shouldn't be there. Every faction plays differently, with the only overlap being some very similar units between Chaos and the Space Marines, but they have different stats/upgrades and have their own faction art. You're also able to customize the factions with the Army Painter, or use one of the several presets corresponding to different factions within the Warhammer universe.The campaign is, in my opinion, the best one in the original set. You only plays one faction, accomplishing static goals, and so it's only good for one runthrough, but that allows it to be the most polished of the bunch. It eases you into the game, introducing concepts slowly enough for you to grasp it all, but you will fail if you don't use everything it teaches you.]So, if you're looking at the series for the first time, or have already decided to buy the set, I'd recommend this one first. It's the best introduction to Dawn of War there is, unless you've found you prefer the incredibly different style of Dawn of War II.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
y 31, 2016
												By creating WH40K:DoW, Relic Entertainment has brought into existence the best Warhammer video game adaption up to date. Dawn of War is a title which doesn't just simply entertain, it takes a special place in the player's memory, and it does so due to two reasons. The first and the more considerable of these two reasons lies in the very fact that this game is set in the grim future of the 41st millennium, a future where there is only war, death and the laughter of thirsting gods. However, in order to adapt such a brilliant setting to the screen of computers, experienced, devoted and skilled game designers had to take matters into their own hands. This is where the second reason for the titles success comes into play - the developers. Relic Entertainment had the right framework to build their RTS upon from the very beginning, but even with such a great basis as the WH40k universe, talent and thoroughness were required so as to make a good quality game. Before DoW, several WH40k titles were already developed for the PC, with most of them being released in the 90's. While these predecessors were usually of good quality, certain factors prevented them from being as accomplished as DoW, graphical limitations being one of them. Relic Entertainment utilized the technology which was available in 2004 to implement the best possible graphics into their RTS, and graphics are indeed one of the most remarkable attributes which Dawn of War possesses, even to this day. The gameplay mechanics are also unique and exceptional, as are all the other aspects of the game.In Dawn of War, Relic Entertainment employed a semi-innovative resource control system. Unlike in some older, well known real-time strategies where the player had to directly gather resources which fueled his armies growth, in DoW the economy revolves around control over strategic points that are scattered all across the battlefield. The amount of the strategic points controlled is crucial since they directly affect the players requisition income, thus forcing the opposing combatants to constantly fight for the control over territory. In addition to strategic points which play the primary resource role and grant requisition, DoW also has a secondary resource called power. This resource is just as essential as requisition, since power is required for researching or upgrading technologies and abilities, and is also spent when deploying advanced units and vehicles. In order to gain power resource points, the commander must build power generator structures either near his base of operations or at special slag deposits which grant more power income. By the time Dawn of War was released, the requisition control system was new but not unheard of, since there were already games that utilized a somewhat similar concept. Massive Entertainment's Ground Control II for an example, which was released approximately three months before DoW, used a system called acquisition in which points were earned through the capturing of victory locations. Later on, Massive Entertainment used the same system in their well acclaimed RTT World in Conflict. In fairness it must be said, that even though Relic's resource control system was at that time both original and well designed, it wasn't actually their invention. They did, however, put this system to good use, because in terms of economical balance, DoW is a perfectly designed RTS. Missions in-game usually alternate between jungles and ravaged urban ruins, with Fog of War being persistent in those areas of the map which either have not yet been uncovered or were abandoned by allied forces. In battle, the environment plays a minor strategic role as well, on account of that in Dawn of War, certain types of terrain can provide troops with either good cover, granting them a protection bonus, or harmful cover which exposes the troops and makes them vulnerable to enemy fire. In general, terrain and the surrounding environment both contribute to the tactical detail of the game, with infantry traversing faster over certain terrain types, while treaded vehicles will move slower. Infantry squads all have morale that affects their combat effectiveness. An infantry squad with broken morale will be much less effective in combat, and will need to retreat in order to replenish their fighting spirit. Squad leaders also give each squad a significant morale boost. Enemy infantry has morale as well, and certain weapons, such as for an example a flamethrower, can break it faster, rendering enemy formations broken and in a state of moral dismay. In Dawn of War, there are four different factions which are anything but similar and are all driven to annihilate each other. All four of these factions have their own distinctive units, structures and strategies. Units can be divided into infantry and vehicles, with infantry groups usually being versatile and possessing the ability to capture strategic points, while vehicles often take an assault force role. Dawn of War provides the player with an immense arsenal of weaponry, including artillery, tanks and walker vehicles. Unlike some RTS games where opposing armies often have visually different but functionally identical units, in DoW units which are exclusive to one certain faction are unique in the sense that they rarely have a counterpart amongst the three other factions. Therefore, all units in DoW are not only distinguishable by their appearance, but also by their abilities and properties. The Tech-Tree in the game is well developed, each faction has numerous types of infantry, vehicles, skills, technologies and upgrades. The player can also upgrade his primary and defensive structures to go higher in the tech tree, further benefiting his fighting force. In the single-player campaign, the player will have the opportunity to play as the Space Marines Blood Ravens chapter, taking the role of Force Commander Gabriel Angelos. Throughout 11 bloody missions, players will first fight against the Ork menace, will struggle against the mysterious Eldar, and will then finally engage against the traitorous Chaos Space Marines. Most of the missions are focused on elimination of the enemy base and army. Dawn of War offers three levels of difficulty, with the "Insane" difficulty level being the most entertaining and challenging one. The gameplay in Dawn of War can be described as balanced, intense and loaded with ceaseless combat action.Dawn of War has detailed, beautiful graphics which appear terrific and well modeled even up to today’s standards, regardless of the fact that the game is over 11 years old. The palette in DoW fits the WH40k's universe perfectly, with darker tones overshadowing the brighter ones. The colors in game are full of contrast, all is dark yet by no means monotonous. Also, the darkness which pervades in the game by no means makes it faded or bleak; the game is rich in color, and everything has it's unique shade, from crimson blood spilled over the crusted earth to the smeared paint on war-scarred vehicle armor. In my opinion, the graphics in DoW are beyond any criticism, and were obviously created by competent individuals. The UI was elaborately designed to resemble a futuristic electronic panel, whilst the menu backgrounds appear as old parchments (with holy dogmas and aphorisms adorning the corners of these parchments). DoW isn't merely a well designed, good quality game, it is a game with a soul, and that alone says much, because such games are very hard to come by. It is worthy of staying in your heart, for once you play it, you suddenly acquire understanding of what an RTS should be like. Relic Entertainment has successfully brought a WH40K RTS to the display of computers, and for that they deserve honours. Dawn of War is the definition of an outstanding real time strategy, and whoever plays it can be fully confident, that his expectation won't be ruined.

content:
er 8, 2013
												I played this game, as well as all of its expansions, back when they were launched. I'm a Red Alert kind of guy, having played Red Alert 1 on the PS1, and Red Alert 2 on the PC. I really didn't care much for other RTS like Age of Empires, which were big at the time.When I got Dawn of War however, it grabbed my attention instantly. It didn't have the humours nature of RA, or the actors during the Cutscenes, however it was dark and the voice acting is full of charisma.The Warhammer 40k universe is a dark one, full of twisted religious notions, which was something new, at least for me.Having had the chance to get Dawn of War on Steam recently, I jumped on the oportunity and I must say that even though the graphics and the interface are dated, the game is as enjoyable to play as ever.The adventures of the Blood Ravens carry on, and I'm delighted to join them once again.I bloody love this game :D

content:
, 2014
												I am a huge fan of the Dawn of War series, I have most of the games (as boxed non Steam copies) but I am looking into getting all my Dawn of War and Dawn of War 2 stuff onto my Steam. I love the Warhammer universe and it fits very well into the RTS genre. In my opinion the Dawn of War series is one of the best RTS series out there, its easy to learn but hard to master and that makes it fun to start playing and never stop! Each pack of expansion content adds a new single player campaign and more playable races/ factions to the game, and most of the packs are even stand alone so you can pick and choose what you want to buy and play without dropping a huge amount of money on all of the content. I feel if you ever get the chance to try the Dawn of War games you should go for it, especially if you like RTS games or Warhammer.We fans dont often get "good" Warhammer games, like one in every 5 games ends up being decent, especially since most of the Warhammer games as of late have been mobile or some variation of cheap/ money grabbing. Dawn of War series has none of that. So again, you will probobly like the game if you have read my review this far. Try it!Update: I went through Sega of America support and they gave me new keys for the Platinum edition of the game, I now have my Dawn of War, Winter Assault, and Dark Crusade on Steam.

Units can be divided into infantry and vehicles, with infantry groups usually being versatile and possessing the ability to capture strategic points, while vehicles often take an assault force role. Dawn of War provides the player with an immense arsenal of weaponry, including artillery, tanks and walker vehicles. Unlike some RTS games where opposing armies often have visually different but functionally identical units, in DoW units which are exclusive to one certain faction are unique in the sense that they rarely have a counterpart amongst the three other factions. Therefore, all units in DoW are not only distinguishable by their appearance, but also by their abilities and properties. The Tech-Tree in the game is well developed, each faction has numerous types of infantry, vehicles, skills, technologies and upgrades. The player can also upgrade his primary and defensive structures to go higher in the tech tree, further benefiting his fighting force. In the single-player campaign, the player will have the opportunity to play as the Space Marines Blood Ravens chapter, taking the role of Force Commander Gabriel Angelos. Throughout 11 bloody missions, players will first fight against the Ork menace, will struggle against the mysterious Eldar, and will then finally engage against the traitorous Chaos Space Marines. Most of the missions are focused on elimination of the enemy base and army. Dawn of War offers three levels of difficulty, with the "Insane" difficulty level being the most entertaining and challenging one. The gameplay in Dawn of War can be described as balanced, intense and loaded with ceaseless combat action.Dawn of War has detailed, beautiful graphics which appear terrific and well modeled even up to today’s standards, regardless of the fact that the game is over 11 years old. The palette in DoW fits the WH40k's universe perfectly, with darker tones overshadowing the brighter ones. The colors in game are full of contrast, all is dark yet by no means monotonous. Also, the darkness which pervades in the game by no means makes it faded or bleak; the game is rich in color, and everything has it's unique shade, from crimson blood spilled over the crusted earth to the smeared paint on war-scarred vehicle armor. In my opinion, the graphics in DoW are beyond any criticism, and were obviously created by competent individuals. The UI was elaborately designed to resemble a futuristic electronic panel, whilst the menu backgrounds appear as old parchments (with holy dogmas and aphorisms adorning the corners of these parchments). DoW isn't merely a well designed, good quality game, it is a game with a soul, and that alone says much, because such games are very hard to come by. It is worthy of staying in your heart, for once you play it, you suddenly acquire understanding of what an RTS should be like. Relic Entertainment has successfully brought a WH40K RTS to the display of computers, and for that they deserve honours. Dawn of War is the definition of an outstanding real time strategy, and whoever plays it can be fully confident, that his expectation won't be ruined.

content:
31, 2014
												A great, classic RTS game and part of the greater Dawn Of War series which is also a treat for RTS and Warhammer 40,000 fans. You can play through multiple storylines as different races that are part of the Warhammer 40,000 universe, and go in depth with the stories as the campaigns progress. The game did a good job of not only mastering the RTS aspect, but also of capturing the essence of the Warhammer 40,000 universe. Capturing key points is a key part of battlefield gameplay in this RTS, and it should be enjoyable for anybody that likes RTS games in general.Once you are done with the campaigns, you can also play in Skirmish mode, or play Online against other players. This game should give you many hours of quality gameplay and I would recommend it to anybody that is interested in the Warhammer 40,000 universe - as well as for new players that want to start getting into it as well.

content:
y 23, 2016
												So this is my first entry into the Warhammer 40,000 universe and I must say I was very impressed. Simple to understand, excessively violent and nearly a perfect strategy game that marks the pinnacle of RTS games of it's era.The story, not to spoil a single thing is superb for an RTS. In my opinion, the story is easily better than that of many games today. With it's twists, turns and full stops, it's a rather moving ride. As you complete missions, the story unfolds a little more until it all breaks down and becomes less of a story to do with missions than all out annihilation. Spending 15 hours with the Blood Raven Space Marine chapter tearing apart Ork by Ork, Eldar by Eldar and Chaos by ♥♥♥♥ing Chaos was a blast and even towards the end never lacked for excitement. However that leads me to slight dismay with the game. Even early in the 15 hours I got sick of playing the same units and the same strategy, the campaign never challanged me to try something different. Maybe it was because I was playing on Normal rather than anything hardcore, but it felt that way. The only time it made me do something strikingly different was when I was pushing away at early linear tutorial missions. However despite this, it's still an excellent game - especially for it's time. Relic, the guys who developed this, along with other award-winning and highly recommended RTS games such as Homeworld and the Company of Heroes franchise did an great job polishing it, making it look strikingly beautiful (of course for it's time) and simple but not bland.Now onto the Skirmish/Multiplayer. Basically the same mode where on varied maps players/AI must battle it out to complete different objectives based on game modes and on many different maps. Map variety is great, even without the expansions and despite not doing much in the skirmish, you could tell that you'd be in for something different just looking at the startup skirmish screen. Whether you play as the Eldar, Orks, Space Marines or Chaos (plus more if you have expansions and use the CD keys on those expansions) you have a varied playstyle and each race is balanced making skirmishes fair each time. However, another point I must bring up, and I've noticed in Relic's other game - Company of Heroes is, that the AI seems to just do the same each game. I may have said the maps make varied gameplay, but mainly against players or if the bots are decently hard. The AI 9/10 do the same thing each time and makes them very predictable leaving them easily destroyable. If you skipped reading that, you're ♥♥♥♥ing lazy, but I came prepared:Pros- Varied Skirmish Maps- Balanced and different factions to play as on skirmish.- Great story was it's twists and turns.Cons- AI often predictable on skirmishes.- Campaign, despite fun, becomes rather repetitive towards the end. One term: Annihilation.Overall I'd rate it easily a 8.5/10.

content:
4, 2015
												BLOOD FOR THE BLOOD GOD!!(ThanksBuketIloveyounohomo!!) Warhammer® 40,000: Dawn of War® is a RTS game by Relic, who did all the other (Good?) Warhammer  games, along with Company of Heroes.  The gameplay revolves screaming out SPACE MARINES ADVANCE!! and generally capturing strategeic points, which gives you one of the game's currencies, Requisition points. The other is obtained by building generators, which gives you power. You do this all while being attacked by Orks, Eldar, and Chaos Marines. Luckily for you, you have Space Marines, along with a large arsenal featuring units, weapons, and vehicles. So do all your enemies, however, so you must reach your vehicles and other powerful units to give you the advantage you need, before your foes reach it and start smacking your face with their stuff. Yeah, its pretty awesome.  I highly recommend this game as it features a great campaign along with some suprisingly humorous dialouge(Mainly between Bale and Sindri), along, and multiplayer with a Skirmish mode(Standard RTS fair, select a faction(s) and fight them), and, of course, multiplayer(Each player controls a faction. Who'd want to play Eldar, I have no clue.).  I recommend this game to really, just about anyone. I'm terrible at strategey, but I loved this game. (And remember, Even in death I serve!)

content:
, 2015
												Played this game like 6-7 years ago and played a lot more than stated by steam.IMO dawn of war is defenitly one of the best RTS games of all time and I reccomend you get the whole franchise.Pros--Large control groups compared to other RTS's of the time, allowing you to control huge amounts of units at once-Great camera system allows you to see the battlefield the way you want to see it withought having to use a completely different set of keys-Training squads instead of individual units makes battles seem more large scale and "war like," compared to other RTS games. -More diverse upgrades than  most RTS games.-COMPATIBLE WITH DARK CRUSADE HYPE-Stunning graphics for its time and since the game is old it will run even on the ♥♥♥♥♥iest of todays computers, bringing fun to all computer gamers :DCons--Multiplayer will ♥♥♥♥ on you-My second/third favorite war40k factions are not in the game :( -Resource system is different from almost every other RTS i've ever played and im frankly not a huge fan, although some people enjoy it.-Army painter isn't as in-depth as you would hope, but is still fun to play around with.-Campaign is relatively easy and then has a sudden difficulty spike, which turns off both veterans playing on hard modes and new players trying to learn the game.

content:
2013
												It includes all them Dawns of Wars! And it acts as the base game when you do. So I'll review that here: Dawn of War was, at the time of its release, the best treatment the Warhammer 40K liscense had ever gotten. It's still way up there, right next to its sequel. It positively -screams- the need for more games in the setting. Sadly, things went ploin-shaped for THQ, so we'll have to wait a while for that to settle out and get studios working on more proper Warhammer games. Until then, you have this to fall back on, and it will catch you, with its innovative (no, really, they are) squad mechanics, lengthy campaign, and wonderful skirmish modes. Some of the sequels and expansions are better, though, so, 4/5

												The Warhammer 40k series of games from Relic Entertainment is a series that never fails to let down, always capturing the feel of the tabletop game in a completely new fashion that is always fantastic, through the Dawn of War series of games and the third person shooter, Space Marine. Dawn of War 1 has a unique gameplay feel to it, as relic made the 2nd one also have a unique feel - giving this game a slot of originality that no other game, not even it's own sequel, is capable of matching. The voice acting, music, and storyline are superb not just by the standards of a real time strategy game but all games in general. And of course, there's the online or offline multiplayer on many maps, all custom made rather than campaign maps simply with redone start posistions and such.This is a fantastic game that stands up to even modern day RTS games with no trouble. I highly recommend getting this game, whether you are a hardcore RTS fan or not much of one at all. It will deliver to everyone, and that is a promise.
