You set up defence in the campaign with 2 - 4 squads starting out then you slowly take over the points and then fortify the points then you steam roll enemy base.Overall, I will give it 7/10 an enjoyable RTS and worth your time. The W40k lore is interesting and kept me going playing the game, I wanted to learn what would happen next.More of a unit based RTS with basebuilding included but not the main point of the game.

y 28, 2016
												The beta period for Dawn of War was one of my favorite gaming experiences ever. Believe it or not, there was a pretty long period of time where the general tone of gamers online wasn't overtly negative and troll-ish, and the whole beta was filled with fantastic players who were down to play this new and exciting entry into the RTS lexicon.That being said, Dawn of War has certainly aged strangely. Since it has been out for nearly twelve years at this point, its kind of a funky game. Video games have grown up and changed a lot since this was new, but that doesn't really detract very much from the overall experience. Widescreen doesn't really work and isn't worth trying to get to work, as a sidenote.The core gameplay is based more around controlling squads of units than building a base. There are still resource nodes to grab on the map, and you still need to be mindful of the tech tree and working towards better units, but most of the game is army and unit based. Each of the races in the game sort of play similarly, with similar ideas, although some asymmetrical aspects are present. The core design is still fun years later, and games versus the AI can be hectic. If you have a buddy who is down to do some 2vAI games, and you don't mind clunky early 2000's interfaces, you'll get some good mileage out of this. The campaign is totally forgettable and only features one race, though. Online seemed to be a ghost town when I tried it out, but that also might be a side effect of the confusing naming of the first Dawn of War game + expansions.You see, the GOTY edition doesn't contain everything, strangely enough. You're still missing the expansions. If you want the complete experience, you'll have to look elsewhere and get the Platinum edition. I got this through a bundle, so I'm not too miffed, but the naming is confusing.Overall, this was a good bit of time for some nostalgia. I had a blast playing a couple of maps and doing most of the campaign, but there isn't much staying power here if you're not a returning player. You might find the design a bit flawed overall, and there are later Dawn of War games that improved on the formula this game established.

content:
4, 2015
												The Gold Edition of Dawn of War was one of the first M-rated games I bought as a teenager, and I always had fond memories of it because it catered to my personal favorite combat strategy: turtling. Nine years later, those feelings are still going strong.For the uninitiated, turtling is the notion of erecting a stiff defensive perimeter, absorbing enemy attacks while establishing one's own economy, then lashing out with the full fury of one's tech tree and crushing the enemy in a swift show of force. Dawn of War's most effective strategy is what I like to call "Turbo Turtle" because of its resource mechanics. Unlike most games which require players to harvest resources from the game world in something of a parallel operation to the military stuff, the two mix together in the form of requisition, gained automatically from capturing various points around the map. This system keeps the game moving because no resource infrastructure is required to build infantry units. Just take a squad or two, capture some points, and you're off and rolling. These points can even have fortifications built on them, keepinig enemies at bay long enough for a force away from the flashpoint to react and engage and allowing the player to hold large swathes of territory (and resources) without desperately trying to get every detail just so to prevent exploits in the defense. (The other resource, power, is produced entirely within the tech tree with bonus areas available on most maps, meaning any shortage is usually self-created.) This keeps the game moving at a reasonable pace and prevents players from turtling for 20-30 minutes while advancing to the next tech level like one might in other RTS titles. This simplified approach keeps the focus on combat and battle tactics rather than letting resource gathering linger in the back of the player's mind.The game also doesn't have players building infantry units piecemeal; instead, infantry come in squads which can be expanded and outfitted with heavy weaponry. The Space Marines - the sole faction the player uses in the campaign - have such powerful infantry that most early missions and even skirmish games can be won with 4-5 decked out squads of their mainline infantry, and the squad as the base unit can result in infantry combat on a massive scale at the climax of a battle. Five full squads of Space Marines puts 45 units under the player's control; mainline infantry for the other races churns out even more individuals, and it's all commanded at the squad level, so, again, no micromanagement.The visuals were quite good for the time, although they haven't held up very well in the nine years since the game's original release. The upside to this is a lack of lag or chug on most modern PCs, even when the battles reach their most frenzied. There are fewer positives to be found with the story (quite dull and rather predictable) and the sound design (the voice acting is downright painful at times), but playing an RTS for the story is like eating a cheeseburger for the pickles; it's nice to have the extra flavor, but it's not really why you bought the burger.Relic hit a home run with this game. Not only did they capture the essence of Warhammer 40,000 and its lore, they also made it something players new to 40k will be interested in and enjoy without getting bogged down in trying to bring 40k's rules to a video game, something other GW-inspired titles (read: Blood Bowl) could stand to learn from. Fun is the most important element of any game, and Dawn of War provides plenty of it. For the Emprah!

Pros:+ Solid storyline+ Bug-free+ Classic RTS Gameplay+ Clever use of flags+ This is our land now+ But do you have a flag?+ Great Multiplayer/matchmakingCons:- Game is a bit short; single-player campaign lasts roughly 20 hours- Only four playable races; later expansions add moreOverall: Warhammer 40k is a fantastic board game franchise, but it's very expensive.  This is a solid introduction to the world in a fun, entertaining package.  If you played this game in its heyday, you really don't need me to tell you it's great.  If you're new, then know that this game stands the test of time, and is still fun so many years later.  It nails the RTS genre, and still looks good.  It plays smoothly, and rewards clever gameplay and tactics.  The later expansions give more campaigns and more opportunities for multiplayer shenanigans, but this game started it all.Bottom Line: Worth playing and replaying, for old and new fans.  Familiarity with the Warhammer universe not required.

content:
, 2015
												This game is a glorious beauty. When I first picked it up I had no idea what I was getting into, never having heard of WH40k outside of scant references in a few corners of the wider Geek/Nerd community. When I first picked it up and played the tutorial, I was a bit put off because I couldn't amass a large force of tanks (a la Supreme Commander and Supreme Commander: Forged Alliance). And why in the world was melee combat still a thing?? I ended up putting it down to play other games until, feeling bored and wanting to procrastinate on studying for finals, I decided to pick it up again, this time approaching the game with the understanding that it is largely infantry-based. I decided to embrace the melee combat as a unique element of the WH40k universe. I created my own army (which was surprisingly fun) and then went and did the campaign. As of writing this I have all but finished it, and I must say that this was surprisingly enjoyable. As someone who can intuitively predict the endings of most movies, I have to admit that during the first half or so of the game I was kept guessing about what would happen. Some of this is undoubtedly due to the fact that this is my first introduction to the WH40k universe (if you're familiar with the franchise you *might* guess what can/will happen next). It is probably one of the more enjoyable campaigns I've played now in awhile.As an infantry combat game, the infantry battles, upgrades, and mechanics are engrossing and satisfying. Base building does have restrictions (you can only build within a radius of the stronghold or strategic points) but it balances the game nicely and is enjoyable.Research is pretty interesting - you unlock new buildings and units by building new buildings and/or upgrading your stronghold/starter building. You can research upgrades for your units at specific buildings (eg, for the Space Marines at least, the armory will give you a research option which will increase the number of special weapons you can carry + gives you access to more weapons like rocket launchers). You can also upgrade you units in the field (eg, dreadnought can be upgraded with an assault cannon or twin laser cannon, predator can be upgraded with all manner of laser weapons, squads can be given a sergeant, etc.).Edit: There are a few bugs, mostly related to saving a game in the middle of playing a campaign mission, etc. These can be overlooked though, they are relatively minor (eg, missing voice queue/background music, etc.). The biggest bug that annoys me is that the game seems to forget to increase your infantry pop cap when you research the last upgrade. This can be worked with but it can be downright frustrating. Bug does not appear to affect the vehicle cap. This game is fun. Even if you're not into War Hammer 40,000, this game is still worth playing. Play it, lest you be accused of HERESY!!8/10 would procrastinate again.

												A solid RTS set in the grim world of Warhammer 40,000. Unit variety and constant revisions to one's strategy keep the game fresh, even for an older title. Its nice to still see stable multiplayer for this game, something which should now continue into the forseeable future. The story-driven campaign has excellent voice acting and intersting mission variety. Be wary that this game does have some trouble launching on some newer graphics cards, however this is easily fixable with some quick config file changes. Overall, if your a fan of real-time strategy or Warhammer 40k, I would definetly recommend this title to you.

er 23, 2015
 Overview  To me, Dawn of War is my favorite RTS games, ever. As much as I love this game, I still think it's a flawed masterpiece on its own. In this review, I'll be going over the story, gameplay, and my likes/dislikes with this game. This is a spoiler-free review, so nothing here will ruin your eperience with this AWESOME RTS! The Story, and Gameplay Dawn of War takes place in a war between the Space Marines, Orks, Imperial Guard, Eldar and Chaos Marines. The game plays pretty smooth, and is quite fun to learn each race and their abilities. I LOVE to play as the Imperial Guard, because they're quite fond to learn.  I dislike the Eldar, though, because over how overpowered they are. The next thing about gameplay, is that the Expansions add such great things in-game.  Likes/Dislikes  Likes:-Contrary to my opinion earlier, I enjoy the Eldar.-More Waagh Banners=More power!-This deserves all the awards it got, but my favorite RTS is still Empire at War.Dislikes:-Not able to play in modern resolution, must get a download with a patched version of the execuatble for modern resolution use.-The Orks vehicles are not very powerful-Space Marines can have quite the unit cap. Final rating  I rate this MARVELOUS RTS a 10/10, it deserved all the awards it got!

												Worth buying! Entertaining animations, territory control as an actual game mechanic as opposed to a general principle, the expansions add new content but are also stand alone and more or less games in their own right, after you have the expansions the original still seems complete and balanced compared to the sequel DOW II which seems more cash grabesque, quite understandable considering warhammers origins as a tabletop but still; easy to learn but hard to master in the same vein as chess but with more explosions and retreating. That is another thing! Retreating is actually a valid tactic! Make a fallback position to heavy cover when ♥♥♥♥ hits fan, beware though that if you turtle in that fantastic invincible making cover your enemy squads can and will spec there squads out with flame throwers and explosives, The wargear mechanic means that while some units are still better than others for specific tasks you can generalize or specialize THOSE units as well! Tanks are scary. Chaos marines flinch easy, Orks splatter, Space marines drown, and Eldar eww.

content:
ry 10, 2016
												I rate Warhammer 40K: Dawn of War (this game still doesn't explain why this game is called 'Dawn of War') Game of The Year Edition 3/5. Ok.Well this game was probably pretty good (3.5/5) when it first came out but like movies, games can age and often not in a good way. By today's standards I'd have to say this game is fairly bland and, particularly during single player campaign, somewhat boring. This is partially due to the relatively drab graphics but is also partially due to the gameplay itself which is, sadly, a little too repetitious, Regardless of whether you play multiplayer, in the single-player skirmish mode or on the main campaign, the game's battles are primarily focused on the need to capture and control certain victory control points. Capturing and holding these control points primarily give you the ability to requisition more soldiers, equipment and vehicles or allow you call for more buildings with which to reinforce.Unfortunately, this kind of tactical battlefield gameplay gets old pretty fast as, regardless of which side you play (they are all pretty evenly balanced against each other), the underlying tactics one must employ change relatively little. Essentially you must build units, capture points and then build more units, reinforce and upgrade your current units and capture more points. The single player campaign attempts to spice things up a bit with story-oriented objectives which require you to do things like eliminate every enemy building or kill a particular enemy. The multiplayer and single player skirmish modes also includes settings which allow those matches to be won and lost if similar objectives are achieved. However, regardless of how victory is to be declared, control points must be captured to get more battlefield resources.Limiting the potentially creative tactical possibilities even further, the gameplay is heavily focused on the deployment of infantry. (Some sides use more light, faster-moving infantry and other sides use heavy, slower infantry but all sides mostly use infantry organized into individual squads which you can individually attempt to control). In the main campaign you can only play as the Blood Ravens Space Marines. There are no air units which you can control while there are a few tanks and other armored units you cannot assign a squad to specifically guard and accompany a particular tank (this has to be done in a more manual fashion), though the game mostly just treats different tanks as merely different types of artillery support for your infantry squads (for example, you cannot use tanks to run over infantry unfortunately).Different units have different roles and are absolutely prevented from working outside of those roles (unless their roles change due to being upgraded). Only infantry can capture control points. Oddly, tanks and armored walkers cannot. The gameplay often feels oddly inflexible as a result. You can assign Heroic units to certain squads but you cannot tell a squad to automatically guard another squad and so forth. I remember back when I played Homeworld I ways setup complex, interlinked guardian roles for all of the units I had so each unit was ultimately protecting (and would automatically reinforce) other units. As in most other tactical games, can't do anything approaching this level of complexity here. This game isn't very subtle. The gameplay is mostly about reinforcing units fast (by clicking on buttons on the lower menu as fast as you can) and selecting different buildings and ordering them to produce ever more units while telling your workers to construct more buildings while telling your infantry to take control points while telling your artillery direct their fire at certain high-importance enemies. Sometimes you get to do flanking maneuvers but sometimes not. There's not a lot of ways to think outside the box in this game. Mostly you just have to try to be fast.In terms of graphics, this game can seem a bit bland by today's standards. The complexity of the textures which this game uses have not aged well. However units have a fair number of animations but the stuff they automatically say when selecting them or giving orders becomes really repetitive really fast (I was happy the game has an option to turn off this particular part of the audio) This game depicts some brutal combat situations with bodies that sort of stack up on the ground (a nice graphical touch) but the characters themselves look, well...cute. They look really, really really CUTE. LIKE OH MY, THOSE SPACE MARINES LOOK SO LOVABLE with their big feet and big shoulders and relatively little heads! The Space Marine Dreadnoughts are even more cutesy and funny. They look like cute walking garbage dumpsters (and they have the deep metal garbage dumpster voices you'd imagine a walking, talking garbage dumpster to have). To be fair, the Chaos forces and the Eldar forces and the Orks generally look a quite a bit less cute though (and this game lets you zoom in to an amazing degree to see each individual close up if you want to though you won't possibly be able to be an effective commander if you try to play the game like from such a view as individuals run into and out of your zoomed-in field of vision). The cuteness might be intentional but Warhammer 40K characters BEING CUTE IS NOT TRUE TO THE WARHAMMER 40K UNIVERSE. Unfortunately because of the extreme cuteness ineptly combined with the seriousness of the dialogue and its suitably heavy-handed delivery, the main campaign's movie scenes are a laugh riot. It is commendable that the designers of this game tried to use the same graphics as the game itself to do most of the cutscenes to advance the plot, but when shown up-close the characters all run like marionette puppets (like in the movie Team America), don't move their lips remotely in sync to the dialogue and well,, LOOK ABSOLUTELY TOO CUTE TO BE BELIEVED!!! If you like inadvertent humor, look up the between-missions scenes. WHAT WERE THEY THINKING?! After a while I started wondering if a Hello Kitty Space Marine was going to show up to perform exterminatus on the planet.The AI does more than adequate job, but then, given the terrible lack of potential tactical options which this game presents you, I'd expect nothing less. The sound is adequate. Although I liked 2 of the pieces of music used in this game the vast majority of it is boring. I got so bored with the music I played music from a media player on my computer while playing several of the larger battles. This game has very few outright bugs and no bugs which are game-breaking. The final boss is not overly difficult though the AI is far more aggressive in the skirmish mode than the main campaign. The main campaign effectively acts as a sort of long tutorial of sorts. The ending of the game is a disappointing cliff-hanger although I suppose I should expect that given the world of Warhammer 40k.Ultimately, given all this, do I recommend this game or not? I'm not sure. I think, in the light of newer games that have come out since which eclipse this one, I do not recommend this game. This isn't a bad game but it is beginning to age badly.

content:
ry 18, 2016
												Damn I love this game ! Having played the Warhammer FPS a few years ago I was attracted to this after playing another Relic game the Company of Heroes series. I've never played the Warhammer table top game but I've at least been in a Games Workshop shop and briefly toyed with board and dice role playing games many years ago. I would guess that some of the developers have played table top RPG's before as some of the kind of humour in that world comes across in this game. I would highly recommend this over Dawn of War 2 as the second game just does not have the same attention to detail, art and graphic design direction that this game has. But DAW2 is a very different game. Here we have Relics calssic attention to detail. The animations and voice acting are incredibly endearing just as we would see a few years later in the first Company of Heroes game. The map design is also solid and believable, where, again, in the second game map objects have been placed badly and you don't feel like your're in a real place.  The sound is also very good. I was listening to a tank firing and it sounded impressive with the shell whooshing off and then a huge explosion as it detonated echoeing off into the map. Sadly that is just not there in DAW 2 although Relic would go on to get it right again in COH2. So well recommended. An excellent diversion and just a very good game.
